contentrichtext.text: {{Hiero|Maat Kheru // "True of Voice"|<hiero>U5:a-Aa1:r-E23-P8-A2-.-or-.-im:t-P8-t</hiero>|align=right|era=egypt}} '''Maat Kheru''' ({{lang-egy|mꜣꜥ ḫrw}}) is a phrase meaning "true of voice" or "justified"<ref name="Allen">Allen, James P. (2000). ''Middle Egyptian: An Introduction to the Language and Culture of Hieroglyphs''. Cambridge University Press. p. 95</ref> or "the acclaim given to him is 'right'".<ref>Rudolf Anthes. "The Original Meaning of Mꜣꜥ ḫrw", ''Journal of Near Eastern Studies.'' Vol. 13, No. 1 (Jan. 1954), p. 50</ref> The term is involved in [[ancient Egyptian afterlife beliefs]], according to which deceased souls had to be judged morally righteous. Once the soul had passed the test, the [[Weighing of the Heart]], he or she was judged to be ''mꜣꜥ ḫrw'' and was allowed to enter the afterlife.<ref name="Allen"/> ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Egyptian mythology]] [[Category:Book of the Dead]] {{Egyptian-myth-stub}}
